ob010a.text: (Mrs. Birge-Liberman) I don‚Äôt have much to add about the points above, but they are all definitely true and I have had similar experiences. What‚Äôs interesting about her is that she tries to care sort of? Like on one of the early fall assignments I said I spent about 17 hours on the assignment (it was a requirement to fill out a coversheet that included that question) and she brought it up at PT conferences and was like ‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm really worried about [My name] because she spent 17 hours on this assignment‚Äù and then proceeded to bash my sleep schedule because ‚ÄúWell my kids go to sleep at 10 pm every day.‚Äù Ok? I work best after 10 pm. Maybe that‚Äôs not the case for your kids, but it is for me. It‚Äôs almost like we‚Äôre different people. And then after I went to her in office hours for help on my final project (she didn‚Äôt really provide help and even said she feels like she‚Äôs being unhelpful) she told my counselor that she should reach out to me because ‚ÄúI seemed stressed about the assignment‚Äù. The counselor was nice, but I also have pretty bad social anxiety, which she knows, because I quite literally had a panic attack when giving my spring presentation, so I‚Äôm not sure why she thought an awkward meeting with someone I don‚Äôt know was going to help? That just added to my stress and rendered me incapable of doing much of anything that day. And she does all of this being ‚Äúconcerned and caring,‚Äù but then doesn‚Äôt actually do anything to help. She doesn‚Äôt work with me to see if there‚Äôs something I could do to be more efficient, or, god forbid, actually state in the rubric what she‚Äôs grading the assignment on so that I don‚Äôt stress so much about not knowing what‚Äôs on her ‚Äúinvisible rubric‚Äù. And then when I go see her in OHs about something she took points off of, she either acts like she‚Äôs the victim (she manipulates the words I‚Äôm saying to act like I‚Äôm a toddler (or maybe a sixth grader considering that‚Äôs who she used to teach) pitching a fit). I‚Äôll be like ‚Äúhey, maybe I missed something. Do you think maybe in the future it could be changed to be explicit so that next year‚Äôs students don‚Äôt have the same problem?‚Äù or ask her where it said to do something, she‚Äôll just say that I ‚Äúshould know [how to interpret the incredibly misleading instructions to fit her ‚Äúinvisible rubric‚Äù] by this point,‚Äù when it‚Äôs literally never been discussed. Anyways, TLDR: She‚Äôs very two-sided/hypocritical, and I genuinely learned more from other students in the class than I did from her (and she constantly acted like that was a good thing). Also this class legitimately took about as much, if not slightly more time & energy than all my other classes (full -time OHS, w/ multiple AP-level classes) combined, I think a lot of that could have been avoided, but Mrs. B was the opposite of helpful with that. (Mrs. Birge-Liberman) I also had Mrs B and I agree with most of the stuff already said because my GPA was on the verge of crying because of this class but I actually do think she is really nice and is knowledgeable about the subject BUT her grading is actually hell I got a 54/100 on an assignment because I turned it in late and it single handedly ruined my grade. She‚Äôs really petty and i got points off on my otherwise perfect presentation because i have a monitor and was looking to the side (like every class) and she said it's ‚Äúweird‚Äù to present like that. (Birge-Liberman) On my CRISPR project last year, I emailed her *2 weeks before the deadline* to ask, very clearly, if I could use both my remaining late passes for the project, because I had other finals on the day it was due.  Her response was ‚ÄúOf course!,‚Äù and then a week after winter break is over, she tells me that I couldn‚Äôt stack late passes and she would take off 30% because I should have read the handbook !  I READ THE FREAKING HANDBOOK THAT IS RIDDLED WITH TYPOS AND INCOMPREHENSIBLE SENTENCES, AND I HAD NO IDEA WHAT IT MEANT, WHICH IS WHY I EMAILED YOU, and this is a perfect representation of what it‚Äôs like to try to deal with her bs for a year.  I would be fine with the condescendingness if she actually graded like we were 6th graders at her old school, but I fully agree with the comment above.  You can spend hours writing 7 perfect pages for an FRQ, but if you didn‚Äôt cite the freaking course materials they give us, sorry, 80%.  The only thing that saved me last semester was the midterm and final that she couldn‚Äôt take points off of as she pleased, and I am genuinely scared for my grade this semester because we have a project instead of a final.

(Mrs. Birge-Liberman 24-25) AVOID BIRGE-LIBERMAN IF AT ALL POSSIBLE. As someone who has taken twelve college courses and been full-time at OHS for three years, during which I‚Äôve taken a wide array of science courses both from and outside the school, I cannot stress enough how terribly this class was taught‚Äîone of the worst experiences of my academic career has been dealing with Mrs. Birge-Liberman. I had to send her EIGHT EMAILS over the course of TWO MONTHS just to get my midterm grade from the FALL SEMESTER ‚Äúfixed,‚Äù and it still isn‚Äôt in Powerschool to this day, by the way. After bringing it up to her, she told me that I submitted my corrections late EVEN THOUGH THEY WERE IN BEFORE DUE. In fact, I know of at least three other students who submitted the assignments AFTER I TURNED IT IN and still got full credit. This isn‚Äôt the first instance of favortism that I‚Äôve seen from her. In addition, she‚Äôll dock points for the most absurd reasons. Your graph is too small? MINUS TEN PERCENT. Forgot Works Cited? MINUS TEN PERCENT. You didn‚Äôt include something that the prompt didn‚Äôt even ask you for? MINUS FIFTEEN PERCENT. You could answer a question flawlessly and with adequate scrutiny, sophistication, and substantive knowledge but still be docked points for not providing real-world examples even though you were never asked to include any. Just because she felt like adding her own invisible rubric. At this point, I imagine most readers would question if what I just mentioned was a report or a satire. No, that was not satire and it was not exaggeration, to my dismay. You WILL  lose points on assignments if they‚Äôre not exactly to her liking (which she doesn‚Äôt tell you until after she grades it, by the way‚Äîhow fun and intellectually stimulating! uh, no, wtf). What‚Äôs truly unfortunate is that Dr. Vetter (whom I‚Äôve heard great things about) is no longer teaching this course‚Äîone for which I was extremely excited for, as a future biomedical engineering major‚Äîmeaning that we‚Äôre now stuck with an AC-incompetent, condescending teacher who seems to have a liking for just bombing your GPA. Throughout almost every class, she treats us all as though we‚Äôre senseless elementary-school children. Maybe it‚Äôs because her past teaching experience was with sixth-graders‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre not sixth graders. Her  demeanor often comes across as condescending and disrespectful of our efforts. Furthermore, if you have any sort of question, she‚Äôll almost always redirect you to her inflexible office hours instead of answering something that would not take more than a minute. Think ‚ÄúIf I expected you to text back a week later, I would have sent you a pigeon.‚Äù Mrs. Birge-Liberman DOES NOT BELONG IN A HIGH SCHOOL ENVIRONMENT and she certainly does not belong at an institution like Stanford Online High School.

(Ms. Hamaoui) I don‚Äôt see what all the hate for her was for. Although she was not the best teacher I have had. Whenever I struggled with assignments I could always email her or message her on pronto and she would reply and was nice with extensions. The things she could have done better are in the above messages, but she was quite enthusiastic.

(Ms. Hamaoui)^(2023-24) Adding to this response: I did not have a good experience with Mrs. Hamaoui. It was not her personality, but rather the fact that she did not do her part as a teacher properly in teaching during class time. I remember the first weeks of the term leading up to the midterm (it was quite bad). Everyone was so confused and would message each other nonstop, trying to see what homework or test was due. This is coming from a person who also attended one of Dr. Mostarshed‚Äôs classes (due to a schedule issue). Dr. Mostarshed had problems to do in class, breakouts, presented the material well, and overall didn‚Äôt confuse or delay the students at all. He was on top of the schedule too, unlike Mrs. Hamaoui.Get him if you can.

(Ms. Hamaoui) (2023-24) On the contrary, we did cover what we needed. Some of the material was certainly easier if you reinforced with the textbook, but it was all at least covered to some extent in class. Ms. Hamaoui is really nice and does give extensions if you need them.

(Ms. Hamaoui) (2023-24) Mrs. Hamaoui was the reason I dropped this class‚Ä¶we didnt cover what we needed for tests and problem sets. I spent 8 hours trying to do a problem set with having no idea what we were doing since we spent classes talking about stuff that weren't important. I remember spending 3 classes (1 hour 10 minutes *3) on one single graphing problem‚Ä¶.

(Ms. Hamaoui) The weekly assignments are optional for a reason, don‚Äôt work too long on them, just use them to check that you know the material. Unit reviews are tricky and not optional, get a start on those early. The labs aren‚Äôt always the easiest but they are what will make you remember the content, so I don‚Äôt object. For the labs read the prompt carefully and start early, they can take a while. The assessments are tricky but they don‚Äôt matter to much for your final grade. Forums don‚Äôt appear in the to-do list, don‚Äôt miss them. The tests are easy if you study, they usually don‚Äôt have super complicated problems like the homework does. As for Hamaoui, I don‚Äôt know why she gets so much hate. If you pay attention in class you will know what you need to for the tests, which are all that really matter. She is super generous with extensions and very accommodating with you and your life. She starts class super early so you can ask questions beforehand. She‚Äôs great.

(Ms. Hamaoui) IF YOU WANT AN EASY A GET HAMAOUI. I know she gets a lot of hate and I‚Äôll admit shes not the best at actually teaching but she lets you do corrections on literally every assignment other than the midterm and final which makes this class so much easier. You can literally go into exams with a 100 because as long as you submit corrections you will have a 100 regardless of how poorly you did on your first attempt or how clueless you are at physics. And tbh we had mostarshed for a bunch of classes as a sub and he was sooo boring and monotone and just reading straight off the slides i dont get why people prefer him over hamaoui. She does cold call in class but she never expects you to know the answer and will never get mad at you or be disappointed if you get something wrong even if its really obvious and she really only cold calls on people who are very obviously not paying attention (visibly talking to someone else on camera, constantly not looking at the screen/being on your phone, or very clearly on another tab/watching videos or movies/playing video games). Also the Pearson assignments and unit reviews are technically not optional but theyre not graded so you do not have to do them or submit your work and you wont get penalized. Also the unit tests are unproctored and have a very very long time limit (I literally took a nap and attended a club meeting while taking one exam) and also arent worth that much in terms of your grade so if you get something wrong you can do corrections but sometimes its just not worth the ffort cause its worth so little.

(Ms. Hamaoui) The beginning of the course had way too much work that we weren‚Äôt warned about and there was an assessment released a day before it was due which was really annoying. But they figured it out and made it more manageable. It‚Äôs not a super fun course.

op010a.text: Erikson‚Äôs teaching is pretty lackluster. Boring to listen to, rambles on until he loses on. I once went to his office hours to ask for help on a homework problem. I spent an hour there and he still couldn‚Äôt solve the problem.
Dr. Erikson is pretty good, just be warned he does not just grade on completion like McKale did

up055.text: This class is‚Ä¶ interesting. Dr. Oas is a good teacher, but the quizzes and tests are 90% of the grade and are extremely difficult, with very little overlap with what is taught in class. Additionally, even though mvc is listed as a corequisite, in the first 2 weeks we were doing second semester mvc. Finally, the homeworks would usually take upwards of 48 hours to complete, partially bc, again, there was very little overlap with what was taught in class.

(Dr. Oas) [2024-25] I started out the year with Dr. Niazi and chose to switch to Dr. Oas after a couple classes. I think this was a smart decision ‚Äì after all, Dr. Oas is the one who designs the course and the exams (I would follow this advice in other high-level STEM classes as well). Having Dr. Oas meant having a teacher who covered all the relevant material needed for the exams. This is especially important because there is no set reading material and you learn from recorded lectures and in-class lectures. Exams are worth like 80%, which is not fun. Start early on the problem sets, go to office hours, and collaborate with your friends. This course is split almost exactly in half between thermodynamics (probably the easiest unit of the whole year) and then optics.

(Dr. Oas) AMAZING INSTRUCTOR. This class made absolutely no sense at first, but Dr. Oas was absolutely amazing with his discussions and (sometimes) even assigning his OWN papers and materials to make everything make sense to us. The content is hard, but the teacher will make sure that you don‚Äôt notice it is. The one complaint I have is that the exams are very difficult, so it‚Äôs not an easy course to get an A in. .

up070.text: (Dr. Oas) [2024-25] I have basically the same thoughts about this course except we had less problem sets (yay) but this time exams were worth 85% (and we had only one exam for the quantum mechanics unit, instead of two per unit as before). I found quantum mechanics and special relativity to be challenging for different reasons, but I‚Äôd say this course is harder than UP055 in general. The final exam on quantum mechanics was so hard.

(Dr. Oas) AMAZING INSTRUCTOR (again). There‚Äôs a lot of visualization required for the first half of this course, and the second half is just absolutely nuts (make sure you review your linear algebra), but once again, Dr. Oas explains things extremely well so you needn‚Äôt worry about it. The material is hard and definitely needs your effort into it, but honestly I think it‚Äôs easier than the first semester (UP055).

oastr1.text: (Ms. Tock) I also highly recommend this class! Ms. Tock is a wonderful teacher. Going into this class, I really didn‚Äôt know about astro at all and tbh I did it because research can look good on a college app. However, I ended up really enjoying the class just for what it was. The only thing is that the class (both semesters) is a relatively large time commitment, but I don‚Äôt regret it at all. Ms. Tock is really dedicated to the students, and she replies to questions ASAP and grades really fast. For the research part, I feel like whether or not you get a good or bad team could make or break the class but I had a really great team and really enjoyed working with them. And the grading is definitely manageable.

Absolutely the best teacher you may ever meet in your life!!! Get her!!  She‚Äôs a quick grader and responds to email really quick with detailed and helpful replies. She made the class very fun and enthusiastic, I like her check-ins, everyone speaks on mic for a little, it updates us for what cool stuff our classmates are doingüòã One thing is that she don‚Äôt accept extensions, but its a 4% grade minus per day. Each assignment is 5 points and always 3 assignments each week. So the 4% is not significant as long as you pace well. The second semester is a research seminar that get you into real science (real data and the excitement for discovering legit unknown things in the universe)ÔºÅÔºÅ
Yes to Dr. Tock she‚Äôs  definitely one of the best at OHS. She loves her students.

Ms. Tock is by far my favorite teacher I‚Äôve had in my whole OHS career. She‚Äôs so enthusiastic, fun, engaged, and grades insanely fast. Astrophysics in the fall is difficult, but not insanely math-heavy like she advertises it to be. The research portion in the spring is so much fun, so interesting, and it is hands on experience with research/real science. 100000% recommend taking this class, for the learning but more importantly, having Ms. Tock as a teacher. Best class at OHS for real.

ob011.text: (Dr. Failor) [2024-25] This is a very chill course but probably not as chill as neuro. This was the first time I sort of abused extensions in an OHS course, because she is so lenient on giving them out. This was helpful in the second semester where you have to turn in drafts of your 20-page review paper. You have to read one research article per week and answer reading questions. The big assignment in the spring is the review article. You also lead class discussions on papers, but she‚Äôs chill with you partnering with someone else. Dr. Failor is super, super nice, and you should also join the science bowl club/homeroom that she sponsors.

ob015.text: (Dr. Vetter) [2024-25] I agree with the above; neuro is not my favorite topic. Just make sure to participate on mic in each class to get the easy 10/10 participation grade. There are no proctored exams, only quizams that are FRQs that you complete by yourself with no outside help.

Dr. Vetter is super chill and an insanely fast grader. There are no exams, just labs and open note FRQs and quizams. Vetter is not a hard grader by any means and the class is refreshing from that standpoint after AP Bio. The course can get a bit dry imo but as long as you do the readings, engage in class, and do your work on time, it‚Äôs very easy to get an A (and honestly a 100 if you try!)
Dr vetter W teacher, easy 100, saving my gpa everyday

up135.text: Extremely rewarding course with excellent instructor. If you took Modern Physics, you must take this course! It will not be stressful. Make sure you have the time set aside for a standard intensive OHS course, but nothing beyond that. You will definitely understand your interests in physics (or disinterest), and will leave the course as a better thinker and with a community you will be able to talk to in the future! Everyone in the class is very diligent and kind, and the instructor is as well, so it forms a nice environment to learn topics you typically don‚Äôt reach until the third or fourth year in undergrad. Just put effort‚Äînotes during class, reviewing slides after class, or similar‚Äîand you will be fine. You will get to do a self-guided project both semesters to explore whatever you like, and you get to formalize it into a paper as well. Very nice addition to your portfolio. Grading -- do not worry, he understands college applications and, if you‚Äôre putting effort, he will work with you. Put in the effort, get the A. Just make sure you do not miss class -- these are the lectures! Also do not slack off, this class builds up, and will become hard if you do not ask questions as they come. Ask questions after class and in OH -- help is there if you want it, but you need to want it. I highly recommend this course to anyone considering a path in CS, Physics, or even other fields. It gives a depthful exposure to allow you to comprehend current literature in a way that allows you to say something intelligent.

jcs01.text: Ehhhhh, Dr thana is ok‚Ä¶overall i just really didn‚Äôt like CS and most of the time had to go on youtube to fully understand concepts

(Dr. Thananjeyan) Genuine 10/10. He‚Äôs very humorous, great in teaching and kinda gives a great class environment overall. He does his best to make sure everyone understands the material and never coldcalls, and accepts resubmissions/edits to assignments. I think the class is getting a bit harder tho, I almost flunked(if you call a B- a flunk) the S1 midterm and final and did pretty bad on the S2 midterm. Still, would recommend, great teacher!!

I had dr. thanan, he was great! He was incredibly nice and funny. It was near impossible to ask questions though‚Ä¶ he always seemed to just repeat what was said in class‚Ä¶ other than that the course is pretty good and the topics are interesting but do note that the second semester is much harder.
(Dr. Thananjeyan) Course was really good, however I have seen that over the years, it is getting harder and harder. Back in 2022-23, the average grade was like a 95 or 96. Now, its like an 89.

(Dr. Thananjeyan) Course was awesome!!!! Hard course from all about computers to python to game theory and permutations/counting/probability. Instructor is so nice and such a great teacher. I learned a lot and enjoy this class. Whoever takes this class, YOU MUST GET Dr. Paramosthy Thanajeyan!!!!!!!

ocs10.text: (Mrs. Rathi) (23-24) Yeah idk you‚Äôll get a lot more help from the internet than Mrs. Rathi, GeeksForGeeks (Geeks4Geeks? forgot) will be your best friend.

(Mrs. Rathi) Oddly I had a different experience with Mrs. Rathi. She was a little passive aggressive but she seems like a fair teacher. She does speak in a monotone during her classes but I didn‚Äôt really see a problem with it. Her redo policy was a tad unclear but otherwise the class was pretty chill and the assignments were relatively straightforward. The only issue I had was with the final project, since she changed the due date to something that was due 2 weeks before the original due date. She did this 2 weeks in advance but it would have been nice to get a warning on this since it made the final project a whole lot more stressful. But yeah it was still a good course.

(Mrs. Rathi) [2023-24] I 100% agree with what has been said above about Mrs. Rathi-- the environment during her class is either stressful, hostile, or both. In addition, Mrs. Rathi sometimes gives really vague instructions on assignments/in class, and then gets annoyed (and/or takes off points) when a good portion of the class misinterprets the instructions?? She also had a very arbitrary participation grading system, based on "the general feeling [of participation from the student]", which I'm not sure what the criteria for that means exactly. The course content itself was very interesting and enjoyable, but I think I would have had a better experience with a different instructor.
Mrs. Rathi is the worst - THE worst. She‚Äôs passive aggressive, clueless about OHS policy, and basically bullies people in class. I wish I had Polacco.

Mrs. Rathi [2024-25] First month and I hate her already. Here are some basic conditions of being a good teacher that she violates:
Do something with class time. Class meetings aren‚Äôt emails, lectures or an assignment, it‚Äôs an interactive time. Figure out something to do with it. Don‚Äôt lecture in a dull monotone if you want people to pay attention.
Don‚Äôt make assumptions. Not everyone who is smiling is distracted. If you KNOW that your class doesn‚Äôt make people smile, do something about it rather than snap at all the smiling people.
You know more than they do. If all of your students are getting the wrong answer, the same wrong answer, that might just mean that they don‚Äôt have an intuitive sense of how computers work. It does not necessarily mean they didn‚Äôt do the reading and need to be shamed on record for it. Also, they can‚Äôt do something as fast as you can just because they understand it conceptually. 
Be respectful. Your students will not learn a thing from a teacher who doesn‚Äôt respect them. Questions are ok and should be encouraged, even if you think you already answered them, because perhaps the student doesn‚Äôt understand your answer. Don‚Äôt, ever, at any point, for any reason, shout at your students calling them CHILD in command tense.
Be understanding. Sometimes life happens to your students. Don‚Äôt keep bugging the person whose mic/camera isn‚Äôt working, they usually can‚Äôt do anything about it until class is out. And please, if you must cold call, don‚Äôt for the love of God cold call THE CRYING KID. Saying ‚Äúoh you‚Äôre crying i‚Äôll pick someone else now‚Äù does NOT fix the mistake you just made.
Be interesting. Students do not pay attention to/remember/care about a boring or hostile meeting. You will not be able to teach anything if you don‚Äôt utilize these, and you will DEFINITELY not be liked.

(Mrs. Rathi) eh. She was very passive-aggressive throughout the class, sometimes I think an attempt to be funny she ended up just coming across a bit rude and would pick out a few students who she just did not like. We had Polacco for a sub for one day, and I am so hyped to have him next year instead. She is super vague and if you ask her to repeat more than once she gets a bit annoyed, ‚ÄúI just told you,‚Äù once a good old, ‚Äúwhy dont you get it?‚Äù, or she just says the same exact thing she did before even if you said I dont understand. She changed the participation requirement halfway through the course, promised extra credit for whoever was on mic the most but did not give it (Said she forgot about it next semester) TO HER CREDIT, whenever I went to office hours her attitude was so different and she was super helpful, and even showed me samples of how something was supposed to be done instead which is amazing. Dont expect that vibe in class though‚Ä¶ its like two different teachers	! you don't do the assignment the way she wanted (which she won‚Äôt necessarily tell you how she does, or the assignment says to do it one way, and she wants it differently you get points off) she takes off 2 points (which for my year you could NOT redo it, it has to be less than an 8, so 7 and below that you can redo, and she would give 8‚Äôs). My only real annoyance was when she looked my code over, and went ‚ÄúYeah that works good,‚Äù but gave me an 8/10.

ocs20.text: Course was super fun! I got Dr Made and he's probably my fav comp sci teacher so far; he taught us how to improve and optimize our coding a whole lot; I get to use a lot of what I learned in extracurriculars as well. He's also super chill and tells funny stories during class so even if he goes deep into topics I never felt like my head was exploding too much. There were like five of us in class and he got to know us all so it was really fun

Course was very fun and engaging, Mr. Polacco is a wonderful teacher. My sister took the course last year and wanted to make a maze game for the final project, which involves material that was several years ahead of the class, so rather than have her choose a new project he gave her a code snippet and a general explanation on how it worked.

Agree with the above^ grading is a little slow but other than that he‚Äôs basically a perfect instructor: super helpful, ready to dive deep into anything you need help with and cover whatever people find interesting. He also spends 4 classes just playing review kahoots instead of doing a pointless lecture around breaks or the AP exam which is awesome.

Course was great, Mr. Polacco is an awesome teacher, and always available if you have any questions. Class discussion sections are super engaging and Mr. Polacco really helps you understand the material. Only feedback is that grading can be a bit slow at times.

ocs25.text: The course content is very nice, the homeworks are NOT! Many of them require you to run algorithms by hand on inputs with like size 15 or something, which at this point is basically busy work. The exams are also like this.

See Programming in C++ comments about Ms. Rathi‚ÄîI second them. Class feels hostile because you‚Äôre constantly being yelled at. She  doesn‚Äôt give you the opportunity to ask questions and have them answered in a helpful manner. You have to answer ‚Äúyes‚Äù when she asks ‚ÄúDo you understand?‚Äù or else she‚Äôll just yell louder and louder and say derogatory comments like ‚ÄúGuys, it‚Äôs simple. Use your brains.‚Äù When you finally say ‚Äúyes‚Äù even if you don‚Äôt understand, she just laughs and goes ‚ÄúSee, it‚Äôs easy‚Äù and moves on. I‚Äôm pretty sure nobody actually understands anything in class. Assignments are graded vaguely. Half the time she takes points off and I have no idea why. I‚Äôm scared to go to office hours to figure out why because she‚Äôll just yell at me more. Every day, I hate the class more and more. TLDR: you have to pretty much self teach yourself complex concepts if you don‚Äôt understand them the first way around because you are not going to have a support system‚Ä¶ Hopefully your TAs are good.

ocs35.text: Dr. Thana is very understanding with late work and‚Äîif you do the bare minimum of talking during class actively, and stay on cam‚Äîwill not grade harshly. He is available after class to answer questions and give help. This class is a low-stress exposure to architecture that will prepare you for university. It may feel like Data Structures at times, with the monotonous tracing-esque problems, but that‚Äôs just CS courses here I guess. There are fun assignments, if you can get yourself to get past the computational part and realize that there is a system underneath. Second semester, you get to do a project for the midterm. For exams, just review assignments EXTREMELY carefully. I would highly recommend you pay attention in class and ask questions. Especially if you‚Äôre a senior, do not pray for it to all click a week before finals when you need to submit applications too. Put effort and you‚Äôll get the A. If you haven‚Äôt done CS classes, it may feel a lot more intimidating, when in reality it‚Äôs very simple. The above comments are not wrong, but he explains in class very thoroughly with analogies, so if you ask in those moments and with those contexts he will better be able to help than random questions (unless there‚Äôs a guiding HW problem). Seems he has a lot of classes back-to-back so he may also just be very busy (seems there‚Äôs one right before ours). I recommend this class to those on the CS path at OHS. It will be a nice way to finish it off.
